Authors:
Diana Marcela Rueda-Ramirez, Jandir C Santos, Nazer Famah
Sourassou, Peterson R Demite, Andres Puerta-Gonzalez, Gilberto J
Moraes
Title:
Morphological details of Africoseius americanus and placement
of Africoseius in Podocinidae (Acari: Mesostigmata) based on molecular
and morphological evidences
Journal:
Journal of Zoological Systematics and Evolutionary
Research
Abstract:
Morphological details of specimens collected from several
localities in Brazil and identified as Africoseius americanus Karg &
Schorlemmer, 2009 are provided. The taxonomic status of Africoseius
Krantz has been debated over the years, with repeated changes in its
familial placement. A phylogenetic study based on the rDNA 18S and 28S
sequences of the Brazilian population of A. americanus and similar data
of 70 taxa representing 11 families of Gamasina indicated Africoseius to
be a member of the well-supported Podocinidae (sensu Lindquist, Krantz
& Walter, 2009) clade. The main morphological similarities and
differences between Africoseius and Podocinidae sensu Lindquist et
al.Â (2009) are listed. Apomorphic characteristics apparently holding
those taxa together are the hypotrichous condition of tibia I (eight and
nine setae instead of ten or more in other free-living Mesostigmata) and
the insertions of av2 and pv2, considerably more distal on tarsi II and
III than in the majority of the free-living Gamasina. Within
Podocinidae, a new subfamily, Africoseinae, is proposed, based on
uniquely apomorphic characteristics of the basitarsal setae of legs II
to IV, a posterior longitudinal extension of the peripodomeric line and
on the attenuated form of the lateral (rather than the medial)
hypostomatic setae.
